page.title: 06MORTHAM TOWER
page.content: Mortham Tower stands on a knoll overlooking the confluence of the rivers Tees and Greta. It was built as a Peel Tower in about the 12th century and sacked by the Scots after Bannockburn in 1314. The Rokeby family house nearby was also sacked about this time and the Rokebys moved into Mortham, building it up into a fortified Manor house against further Scots forays. Thomas Robinson bought the land after the Civil War and built Rokeby Hall. Mortham now fell into decay until in 1938 it was bought by William Rhodes-Moorhouse whose plan to restore it was interrupted by the war of which he became a victim. After his mother's death in 1975, the restoration was completed by the Batemans, the present owners, to make this one of the oldest inhabited houses in the north.
